title: Welcome To My Blog
text:
Hello!
I am Claudia Robles, a senior at University of Illinois Urbana Champaign majoring in Information Sciences.
Some of my hobies:

I enjoy crocheting a lot! I started a two years before the pandemic in 2019. During the pandemic, I became more interested in it and started creating different items, such as key chains and hats.
I also enjoy playing some instruments! Since 4th grade, I’ve played the violin. Because of my initial interest with that instrument, I decided to learn others. I’ve tried the cello, piano, and guitar!
While I enjoy creating music, I also enjoy listening to music! Some of my favorite genres are classical music, pop, rap, and rnb.

Interests:

Currently, I am very interested in video games. Over the summer, I celebrated my 21st birthday and decided to get a game console! I’ve wanted one since it came out a few years ago, but I was just recently able to purchase it. I know spend time playing Spider-Man, Call of Duty, Sack-boy, and more!

Achievements:

During my sophomore year in high school, I was able to audition and get a spot in my city’s youth symphony orchestra! I played both 1st and 2nd violin sections.
When it was time to attend high school, I was given the opportunity to apply for different academies. We had one for STEM, Languages, Honors and Gifted, and Music! I applied for the Music Academy and Languages Academy. I was able to get into both and in the end, I chose the languages academy to become trilingual!

Fun fact:

My favorite number is 7!


3+4

[1] 7

title: Analyzing College Football
text:
Currently, I am attending the University of Illinois in Urbana-Champaign. Our football team did well during the Fall 22 season, hence I was inspired to look at a data set that was created by a UIUC professor: Professor Wade Fagen-Ulmschneider.
He has his own personal github:
wadefagen (Wade Fagen-Ulmschneider) (github.com)
Where he has all the data sets he has created.
Beginning of analysis:

library(tidyverse)

── Attaching core tidyverse packages ──────────────────────── tidyverse 2.0.0 ──
✔ dplyr     1.1.3     ✔ readr     2.1.4
✔ forcats   1.0.0     ✔ stringr   1.5.0
✔ ggplot2   3.4.3     ✔ tibble    3.2.1
✔ lubridate 1.9.2     ✔ tidyr     1.3.0
✔ purrr     1.0.2     
── Conflicts ────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse_conflicts() ──
✖ dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter()
✖ dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()
ℹ Use the conflicted package (<http://conflicted.r-lib.org/>) to force all conflicts to become errors

library(skimr)


football <- read_csv("https://raw.githubusercontent.com/wadefagen/datasets/master/illini-football/illini-football-scores.csv")


skim(football)

From the previous code, we can see that we have a total of 1284 rows. This means, this data set contains 1284 rows worth of data from games played by the Fighting Illini football team. Below, I decided to filter by the column name “Result” where it says “W,” meaning when the team was able to win a game against their opponent.

football %>%
  filter(
    Result == "W"
  )

# A tibble: 617 × 9
   Season Date   Location Opponent OpponentRank Result IlliniScore OpponentScore
    <dbl> <chr>  <chr>    <chr>           <dbl> <chr>        <dbl>         <dbl>
 1   2022 8/27/… vs.      Wyoming            NA W               30             6
 2   2022 9/10/… vs.      Virginia           NA W               24             3
 3   2022 9/22/… vs.      Chattan…           10 W               31             0
 4   2022 10/1/… @        Wiscons…           NA W               34            10
 5   2022 10/8/… vs.      Iowa               NA W                9             6
 6   2022 10/15… vs.      Minneso…           NA W               26            14
 7   2022 10/29… @        Nebraska           NA W               26             9
 8   2022 11/26… @        Northwe…            3 W               41             3
 9   2021 8/28/… vs.      Nebraska           NA W               30            22
10   2021 10/2/… vs.      Charlot…           NA W               24            14
# ℹ 607 more rows
# ℹ 1 more variable: Note <chr>


We see that we have a total of 617 rows, which is crazy to me! Our football team has not won a lot of games. Our first few rows are from the Fall 2022 season, so you can see we have been performing better in terms of winning or losing.
Wins at Home vs. Away:

football %>%
  filter(Result == "W",
         Location == "@")

# A tibble: 207 × 9
   Season Date   Location Opponent OpponentRank Result IlliniScore OpponentScore
    <dbl> <chr>  <chr>    <chr>           <dbl> <chr>        <dbl>         <dbl>
 1   2022 10/1/… @        Wiscons…           NA W               34            10
 2   2022 10/29… @        Nebraska           NA W               26             9
 3   2022 11/26… @        Northwe…            3 W               41             3
 4   2021 10/23… @        Penn St…            7 W               20            18
 5   2021 11/6/… @        Minneso…           20 W               14             6
 6   2020 11/14… @        Rutgers            NA W               23            20
 7   2020 11/21… @        Nebraska           NA W               41            23
 8   2019 9/7/2… @        UConn              NA W               31            23
 9   2019 10/26… @        Purdue             NA W               24             6
10   2019 11/9/… @        Michiga…           NA W               37            34
# ℹ 197 more rows
# ℹ 1 more variable: Note <chr>



football %>%
  filter(Result == "W",
         Location == "vs.")

# A tibble: 393 × 9
   Season Date   Location Opponent OpponentRank Result IlliniScore OpponentScore
    <dbl> <chr>  <chr>    <chr>           <dbl> <chr>        <dbl>         <dbl>
 1   2022 8/27/… vs.      Wyoming            NA W               30             6
 2   2022 9/10/… vs.      Virginia           NA W               24             3
 3   2022 9/22/… vs.      Chattan…           10 W               31             0
 4   2022 10/8/… vs.      Iowa               NA W                9             6
 5   2022 10/15… vs.      Minneso…           NA W               26            14
 6   2021 8/28/… vs.      Nebraska           NA W               30            22
 7   2021 10/2/… vs.      Charlot…           NA W               24            14
 8   2021 11/27… vs.      Northwe…           NA W               47            14
 9   2019 8/31/… vs.      Akron              NA W               42             3
10   2019 10/19… vs.      Wiscons…           NA W               24            23
# ℹ 383 more rows
# ℹ 1 more variable: Note <chr>


Now I wanted to compare the wins we have at home games vs. the wins we have during away games. From the number of rows (207 for at Home games and 393 for Away games), we see that we have more wins from playing away games!

title: Analyzing Student Performance
text:
As a current student at Univeristy of Illinois Urbana-Champaign, I like to know which as the best and easiest classes to take (I also like to take hard ones of course, I love science and math). I was inspired to look at a data set that was created by a UIUC professor: Professor Wade Fagen-Ulmschneider.
He has his own personal github:
wadefagen (Wade Fagen-Ulmschneider) (github.com)
Where he has all the data sets he has created. He generated a data set that combines all information in regards to classes, gpa, and professors on campus.
Beginning of analysis:

library(tidyverse)

── Attaching core tidyverse packages ──────────────────────── tidyverse 2.0.0 ──
✔ dplyr     1.1.3     ✔ readr     2.1.4
✔ forcats   1.0.0     ✔ stringr   1.5.0
✔ ggplot2   3.4.3     ✔ tibble    3.2.1
✔ lubridate 1.9.2     ✔ tidyr     1.3.0
✔ purrr     1.0.2     
── Conflicts ────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse_conflicts() ──
✖ dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter()
✖ dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()
ℹ Use the conflicted package (<http://conflicted.r-lib.org/>) to force all conflicts to become errors

library(skimr)


gpa <- read_csv("https://raw.githubusercontent.com/wadefagen/datasets/master/gpa/uiuc-gpa-dataset.csv")


skim(gpa)

I loaded in the data set and see some information that I find interesting. The first two things I noticed are Subject and the number of students that got each letter grade.

top_10 <- head(gpa[order(gpa$A, decreasing = TRUE), ], 10)
print(top_10)
